Hattie Watson Holmes

Hattie Holmes

Themes

Athletics
Greek Life
Teaching & Education

Biography

Hattie Elizabeth Holmes, born Hattie Elizabeth Watson, was an African American student at Miami University from the fall of 1929 to the spring of 1933. The oldest of four siblings born to Dock and Essie Watson, Hattie was born on April 23rd, 1911 in Middletown, Ohio, where her father worked at the local steel mill. She attended Middletown High School, graduating in 1929. Hattie enrolled in Miami that fall, majoring in education. An accomplished student athlete, she played soccer, ran track and field (where she set a discus record at the annual Women’s Field Meet in 1932), and was a member of the Women’s Athletic Association on campus. During her senior year, Hattie received the “M” sweater, the most prestigious award that a student athlete in the Women’s Athletic Association can earn. She was also a founding member of Kappa Sigma Delta, organized in 1929 as the first known African American student organization on campus. Hattie and the fellow members of Kappa Sigma Delta unsuccessfully petitioned for the organization to be recognized as an official fraternity in 1932— it would take another six years of operating as an unofficial student organization for Kappa Sigma Delta to be recognized by Miami under the name “The Colored Students Club” in 1938. Though Miami did not have a chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha— the first intercollegiate, historically African American sorority— while she was a student, there was an Ivy Leaf Pledge Club on campus beginning in 1931, allowing Miami women interested in joining AKA to become candidates for initiation in surrounding undergraduate chapters. Many of these women, including Hattie, were initiated into AKA through the nearby Omicron chapter at the University of Cincinnati. She and the other Miami AKAs were therefore considered “Stray Greeks”, as they belonged to a group of students whose fraternity or sorority were not represented on Miami’s campus. Miami would eventually charter their own chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha in 1977. After graduating from Miami in 1933, Hattie returned to Middletown and began teaching for Middletown Public Schools. She married Samuel Holmes, a steel mill worker, in the late 1930s. They had two children together, Marilyn and Walter. Hattie passed away on May 27th, 1978 at the age of sixty-seven.

Credits

Written by Laurel Myers, (4, History & American Studies, 2023)
